relatedPosts.headline: Rise of digital workplaces boosts Whispir’s customer base
relatedPosts.body:
Cloud communications software company Whispir has added a record 77 net new customers to its growing base, as companies and governments speed up their digitisation thanks to COVID-19.

New customers, which hailed from government bodies, emergency services, the education sector and increasingly retail brands like Chemist Warehouse, lifted Whispir’s total customers to 707, a 39 per cent rise on the previous corresponding period.

“We had a record quarter one, which is normally a really quiet quarter,” Whispir chief executive Jeromy Wells said. “So to see that momentum come through for the half was really encouraging. There was record customer adds, and those customers will then incrementally grow as they start small and adopt more use cases.”

The software company’s annualised recurring revenue was up 29.2 per cent to $47.4 million for the half compared to the previous corresponding period. It incurred an operating loss before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) of $1.8 million, down from an operating loss of $4.76 million last year. The bottom line loss was $3.46 million.

Mr Wells said existing customers expanding their use and spend on Whispir was the primary driver behind revenue growth for the half.

Following the results, Whispir shares were trading down 1.19 per cent at $4.20 during Thursday morning’s trade.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: House price rise the next plus for Beacon Lighting
relatedPosts.body:
The chief executive of lights, lamps and ceiling fans retailer Beacon Lighting says rising house prices in Australia should help push sales higher and add extra momentum to the big re-direction of spending to mini-renovations which has been under way for months.

Beacon more than doubled profits in the December half as people spruced up their homes with the extra cash that would have usually been directed to travel and eating out in the COVID-19 pandemic.

Chief executive Glen Robinson said the the shift out of cities to regional centres by some people was also a long-term plus. “That should be quite positive to our business,” he said.

Beacon had been able to deliver “exceptional” results over the six months to December 27 at a time when its Melbourne retail stores were shut for 111 days from August to October during lockdowns, he said.

Rising house prices were traditionally a forerunner for people to invest more in their homes. Commonwealth Bank economists on February 15 signalled they expected house prices to rise as much as 16 per cent over the next two years.

Beacon also trumpeted that it had delivered the impressive jump in profits without receiving any JobKeeper payments for the six months ended December 27.

Profit margins climbed to 14.6 per cent from 7.8 per cent a year earlier.

The company lifted its first-half dividend by 62 per cent to 4.2¢ per share, to be paid on March 12.

Total sales were up by 23.5 per cent to $151 million, while net profit was up 133 per cent to $22.1 million. Online sales climbed by 111 per cent to $14.4 million but still only represent about 10 per cent of total sales.

Full story here.

relatedImages.description: Beacon Lighting CEO Glen Robinson says the shift out of cities to regions should be positive to the business.

relatedPosts.headline: Sonic Healthcare earnings soars on COVID-19 testing
relatedPosts.body:
The nation’s largest pathology player Sonic Healthcare’s revenue jumped 33 per cent to $4.4 billion in the first half of the 2021 financial year as COVID-19 testing surged around the world.

Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) surged 89 per cent to $1.3 billion in the six months to December 31, while net profit vaulted 166 per cent to $678 million, beating many analyst expectations.

While no guidance was provided, in October Sonic noted it gained significant revenue and earnings from COVID-19 testing in the first quarter.

On Thursday the $16 billion company, which has operations in eight countries, said it leveraged its existing infrastructure to perform than 18 million COVID-19 PCR tests to date in 60 laboratories globally.

By mid-morning AEDT, shares in Sonic gained 51¢, or 1.5 per cent, to $34.09 each.

Sonic’s global base business revenue for routine testing (ex-COVID-19 testing) was 1 per cent lower than a year ago, a significantly lower impact than in the first few months of the pandemic.

The group increased margins in both its laboratory and imaging operations. Its balance sheet remains strong, with gearing at record lows and it has $1.3 billion of liquidity available to splash out on acquisitions.

Chief executive Colin Goldschmidt said the strong financial results for the half year reflect the millions of COVID-19 PCR tests performed across the globe as part of combating the pandemic.

The board declared an interim dividend of 36¢ per share, up 2¢, payable March 24. This small increase in dividend was queried by JP Morgan analyst David Low, who asked if there were any plans for higher payouts to shareholders in line with the profit increase.

Dr Goldschmidt said the board took a conservative position and wanted to strengthen the balance sheet.

He pointed to several joint ventures and government contract negotiations currently underway across Australia, the UK, the US and Canada.

Dr Goldschmidt previously called the 2020 fiscal year the most challenging in the 33-year history of the company, which also operates radiology imaging services and a primary care unit, IPN Medical Centres.

Sonic is the largest private pathology operator in Australia, where organic sales grew by 26 per cent in the year, helped by robust growth from COVID-19 tests. Its base business grew by 5 per cent.

Dr Goldschmidt provided no 2021 earnings guidance, but noted that January and February revenue trends remain robust.

He expects that COVID-19 testing will continue well into the future, despite vaccines being rolled out around the world.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: ‘Timing of Aussie bubble unclear’ says Auckland Airport
relatedPosts.body:
Auckland Airport has forecast there will be no two-way travel bubble with Australia until July at the earliest as the ASX-listed company reported an 81 per cent drop in interim net profit to $28.1 million.

“The timing of the Aussie bubble remains unclear,” said Auckland Airport’s chief executive Adrian Littlewood. “We just don’t know.”

While airlines say they have plenty of capacity for flights between Australia and New Zealand, it remains unclear whether the COVID-19 vaccines, which have arrived in both countries, will make it easier for a travel bubble to start, he said.

But the strategies of the Australian and New Zealand governments towards managing COVID-19 appeared to have converged over time, with short lockdowns during virus outbreaks becoming more common in both countries, he said.

The airport believes people will put up with “a bit of disruption” from lockdowns if it meant they can travel to see family and friends, he said.

The airport wants more clarity from the New Zealand government on the thresholds that need to be reached for a a two-way, quarantine free travel bubble to occur.

But it is taking a cautious outlook on when a bubble may start, and is assuming for the purposes of earnings guidance that it will not happen before July.

The airport expects to take an underlying loss of between $35-$55 million over the full year following a $10.5 million underlying loss in the first half.

New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has previously said she was considering opening a full two-way travel bubble between Australia and New Zealand by the end of March.

But Australia’s one way quarantine-free travel bubble with New Zealand, which started in October but has been interrupted by virus outbreaks, was suspended again on February 15 after an outbreak in Auckland.

The airport’s total passenger numbers fell 73 per cent to 2.8 million in the six months to December compared with the same period a year earlier.

Domestic passengers numbers slid 45 per cent to 2.6 million, while international passengers (including people in transit) tumbled 97 per cent to 187,003.

The airport said it supports “traffic light” systems to categorise countries’ COVID-19 risk and has been trialling rapid saliva tests with staff that it says could also potentially be used by flyers in future before boarding planes.

The airport, which has about $1.6 billion in liquidity after raising capital last year, will not pay an interim dividend.

But it has cut capital spending in fiscal 2021 to $200-$230 million from $250-$300 million previously.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: Woodside holds firm on Scarborough after $US4b loss
relatedPosts.body:
Woodside Petroleum has doubled down on its target to give the go-ahead in the December half on its $16 billion Scarborough gas project in Western Australia, despite slumping to a $US4.03 billion ($5.2 billion) net loss for 2020.

“Scarborough remains firmly on track for a targeted FID [final investment decision] in the second half of 2021, with around 50 per cent of our expected equity gas production now under contract,” chief executive Peter Coleman said.

However the decision remains contingent of a successful sell-down of equity in the Pluto-2 LNG expansion project, which would process most of the gas, noted chief financial officer Sherry Duhe.

She said infrastructure investors were showing keen interest in the project, and it was also possible another type of buyer could take both an interest in Pluto-2 and the Scarborough gas field, where Woodside has restarted negotiations on a possible sale now that market conditions have improved.

Woodside also still has to nail down commercial agreements with existing Scarborough partner BHP on gas processing, a deal that is now expected this quarter after multiple delays.

Final environmental and licence approvals are also still required, and are “progressing,” Woodside said.

The heavy bottom line loss for 2020 was caused by weighty write-downs taken in the June half, while underlying earnings slumped more than 50 per cent as lower prices took their toll.

Before one-time items, earnings slipped to $US447 million from more than $US1 billion in 2019, despite record full-year production of 100.3 million barrels.

“Our disciplined balance sheet management has safeguarded Woodside’s financial resilience and positioned us to take advantage of emerging growth opportunities as markets recover,” said Mr Coleman, who has advised he will retire later this year.

“The potential strength of that recovery is already being signalled by the recent increase in oil price and record spot LNG prices achieved in Asia over the northern hemisphere winter.”

Woodside declared a dividend of US12¢ per share, taking the full-year payout to US38¢, down 58 per cent from 2019. The payout surprised some analysts who expected a lower figure ahead of the major investment in Scarborough and as Standard & Poor’s reviews the company’s BBB+ credit rating.

Shares in Woodside were down 2.4 per cent at $25.35 in mid-morning trading.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: Seven Group boss tips more takeover activity
relatedPosts.body:
Seven Group Holdings managing director Ryan Stokes sees low interest rates coupled with confidence in the economic outlook fuelling an increase in corporate activity in the next 12 months.

Mr Stokes said the Australian economy had shown amazing resilience through the COVID-19 pandemic and snap lockdowns across the states.

“I think a low interest rate environment coupled with strong liquidity from lenders will support that (an increase in corporate activity),” he said.

“It is probable to see more M&A activity. I think that is likely to be a theme. From our perspective, we are certainly very confident with our position, our balance sheet and the strength of our operating businesses.”

Mining and construction machinery business WesTrac again led the way for Seven Group, controlled by Mr Stokes’ billionaire father Kerry, in the six months ended December 31.

Seven Group reported underlying net profit after tax of $246.7 million for the first half, down 3 per cent from $254.7 million for the same period in fiscal 2020.

Revenue grew 4 per cent to $2.36 billion and underlying earnings before interest and tax slipped 5 per cent to $396.1 million.

WesTrac contributed $211.4 million to earnings, up 14 per cent, with its performance driven along by big miners entering the commissioning stage with new iron ore projects in Western Australia.

Mr Stokes said big mining fleet deployments were underway with Westrac’s facilities at Guildford in WA building 10 trucks and one hydraulic excavator a month.

In the gold sector, Northern Star Resources is spending $250 million to replace the fleet at Kalgoorlie’s Super Pit with WesTrac supplied Caterpillar trucks.

Mr Stokes said WesTrac was also seeing strong demand in both the resources and construction segments, with the dealerships in WA and NSW topping Caterpillar’s growth rankings in construction.

Seven Group’s other operating business, Coates, found the going tougher with the machinery hire business hit by weaker demand in east coast metro markets.

Coates management cut costs as revenue fell 7 per cent to record a slight increase in underlying earnings to $105.3 million.

Seven Group’s energy portfolio, chiefly a big stake in Beach Energy, took the biggest hit with underlying earnings slumping 54 per cent to $35.5 million on the back of lower oil prices.

The group holds a 15 per cent interest alongside Shell (82 per cent) in the two trillion cubic feet Crux gas field project and said it was working on a final investment decision on the project, seen as a source of backfill for Shell’s troubled Prelude floating LNG plant off the coast of WA that resumed production in January.

The Seven Group results included a $104 million market-to-market impairment reversal on the value of its controlling stake in Seven West Media, where asset sales and cost cutting over the past 12 months have reduced net debt by $241 million to $329 million.

Mr Stokes said the group’s industrial service portfolio, which includes WesTrac, Coates and now a 20 per cent stake in Boral, was benefiting from both accelerated mining production and economic stimulus measures to boost building and infrastructure activity.

Seven Group said its focus with Boral after investing $854 million and securing board representation was to support management in resetting business to improve returns.

The group maintained its guidance for WesTrac to deliver high single-digit growth for the full year and Coates to deliver low single-digit growth in underlying earnings.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: Coca-Cola Amatil cuts dividend as profits fizzle
relatedPosts.body:
Coca-Cola Amatil cut its final dividend by more than 30 per cent after underlying net profit fell 13.6 per cent to $340.3 million, in line with recent guidance, dragged down by weaker soft drink and bottled water sales.

The bottler’s bottom line net profit plunged 52 per cent to $179.9 million after it booked $203 million in one-offs, including “fighting fit” restructuring costs, $7 million in costs incurred in connection to Coca-Cola European Partners’ offer and a $176 million impairment of the Indonesian and Paradise Beverages businesses and investments in the Australian Beverage Co and Made Group.

The result reflected the impact of lower soft drink, water and juice volumes on Amatil’s fixed cost base and a consumer shift to lower-margin drinks such as multi-can packs for at-home consumption.

Sales fell 6.3 per cent to $4.8 billion but momentum improved as the economy reopened, with December-half revenues falling 3.3 per cent after a 9 per cent decline in the June-half.

Volumes across the group fell 8.4 per cent but Australian volumes returned to growth in the December quarter, for the first time in years, and volumes in New Zealand rose for two consecutive quarters. This offset an 18.7 per cent drop in volumes in Indonesia, where the pandemic is still uncontrolled.

Group managing director Alison Watkins said the volume growth that emerged in the December quarter in Australia and New Zealand had continued in January and February and volumes exceeded those in the same periods in 2020 and 2019.

However, trading in Indonesia and Fiji remained challenging.

Ms Watkins said CCA was in better shape than before the pandemic after cutting costs through the “fighting fit” program by $140 million, $60 million of which were permanent savings. CCA had identified another $85 million of savings to deliver by 2022.

Amatil cut its final dividend to 18¢ – well short of analysts’ forecasts of around 25¢ – from 26¢ a year-ago. The value of the final dividend will be deducted from Coca-Cola European Partners’ $13.50 a share offer.

The 2020 results are likely to be the last for Amatil as a listed company and the last for Ms Watkins, who took the helm in March 2014.

The bottler’s 50-year life on the Australian stock exchange is set to come to an end after Coca-Cola European Partners raised its takeover bid to $13.50 a share from $12.75 after major shareholders indicated the initial offer was too low.

The offer, which Coke Europe has declared final, is likely to win over major shareholders such as Martin Currie Australia, Antares Capital, and Pendal Group and hedge funds who bought stock in recent months in the expectation the bid would be raised.

Shareholders are due to meet in mid-April to vote on the offer, which needs 75 per cent approval from shareholders not associated with 30.8 per cent shareholder The Coca-Cola Co.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: ‘It’s going to get messy’: Origin CEO
relatedPosts.body:
Origin Energy chief executive Frank Calabria has warned of a “messy” fall-out from the ultra-low wholesale prices on the national electricity market that helped almost cancel out net profit for the giant power and gas supplier in the December half.

“These wholesale prices are unsustainable:.There will be a supply response, it’s just whether it will be planned or unplanned,” Mr Calabria said after Origin saw bottom-line earnings plunge 98 per cent to just $13 million in the first half of 2020-21.

Origin has already temporarily halted output at one unit of its huge baseload coal plant at Eraring on NSW’s Central Coast amid wholesale prices at six-year lows due to a flood of cheap renewable energy onto the market. Mr Calabria’s comments suggest other less flexible plants may suffer unexpected outages as owners cut back investment amid poor returns.

Such a voluntary cutback in generation as at Eraring is highly unusually in what is typically the peak demand month requiring full output from all generators, and in stark contrast to the situation 12 months ago in a sweltering summer and in a pre-COVID-19 climate with stronger electricity demand.

“One year on it’s very different,” Mr Calabria said, pointing to some external one-off factors such as the COVID-19 pandemic, which has softened electricity demand, and the milder summer, but also to more structural trends such as increased renewable power, partly driven by government policies.

The comments come after Energy Security Board chair Kerry Schott warned earlier this week that coal power plants are “going broke” and some risked closing four or five years before the end of their rated life. Brett Redman, CEO of Origin’s rival AGL Energy, last week said some black coal power generators were struggling to cover their cash costs.

Mr Calabria said Eraring, the country’s biggest coal power generator with 2880 megawatts of capacity, is relatively well off but that those with less flexible generation or with take-or-pay coal purchase contracts will be worse affected.

“Everyone will have to make their own assessment around that,” Mr Calabria said. “I think it’s going to be a pretty messy period of time”

The drop in wholesale power prices prompted Origin to warn of more “challenging” times ahead for its core energy markets business, with profits expected to drop further this June half and continue softer into fiscal 2022.

But Origin looks set to reap benefits from its diversified business, with a brighter outlook for the Australia Pacific LNG venture in Queensland, which should benefit from the rise in oil and LNG prices this half.

Bottom-line earnings dived 98 per cent to $13 million in the six months to December 31, while underlying earnings more than halved to $224 million.

That profit figure before one-time items still beat consensus expectations of $159 million, with analysts at UBS, RBC Capital Markets and Morgan Stanley all saying the result beat their expectations.

Origin, which warned earlier this month of a two-year hit to profits from lower wholesale power prices, trimmed its interim dividend to 12.5¢ per share from 15¢ a year earlier.

The softer outlook for energy markets caused Standard & Poor’s earlier this month to flag a possible cut to Origin’s BBB credit rating.

Chief financial officer Lawrie Tremaine said Origin remained committed to its BBB rating and believed it could both invest in growth and continue to pay out 30-50 per cent of cash flow in dividend. But Origin “needs to progress with caution”, Mr Tremaine said.

Moody’s echoed S&P’s concerns on Thursday, with vice-president Nicholas Chapman describing Origin’s results “at the weaker end of our expectations”. He said they “further highlight the amalgam of headwinds affecting the energy sector”.

Shares in Origin were down 2.4 per cent at $4.49 in mid-afternoon trading.

Origin restated its guidance from earlier this month, signalling full-year underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation of between $1 billion and $1.14 billion for the energy markets business. That signals a significantly weaker second half after the $635 million reported for the first half, which was down 12 per cent.

Production for APLNG for the full year is expected to be between 687 and 705 petajoules, and the venture is expected to break even in terms of paying a distribution to Origin at between $US24 and $US28 per barrel of production, including finance costs.

Origin said it expects to get a cash distribution from APLNG, of which it owns 37.5 per cent, of between $575 million and $675 million at a realised oil price of $US43 a barrel.

relatedPosts.headline: Santos records $460m net loss
relatedPosts.body:
Oil and gas giant Santos has blamed lower international oil prices for a net loss after tax of US$357 million ($460 million).

Following on from two major write-downs in the past year, its full-year results on Thursday confirmed the tough year for the company.

Despite the $460 million net loss, the South Australian-based company delivered an underlying profit of US$287 million ($380 million).

Santos chief executive Kevin Gallagher said the company was now well-placed for a pick-up in 2021 on the back of $US740 million ($574 million) in free cash flow.

Santos also had paid back the federal government $4 million in JobKeeper payments it had accessed during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Mr Gallagher said the company was on “the home straight” to make a final investment decision on its Barossa LNG project in the first half of this year and was also making “significant progress” on its Dorado project.

The company was also undertaking its two-year appraisal project for the Narrabri gas project which received state and federal approvals last year.

Santos will pay a final dividend of US5.0 cents per share fully-franked, in-line with the previous year’s final dividend. This brings full-year dividends to US7.1 cents per share fully-franked.

Analysts said the Santos full-year results were in line with market expectations.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: Perpetual pins future to international expansion
relatedPosts.body:
Active fund manager Perpetual has been whacked by further redemptions and outflows in its Australian business but is pinning its hopes on a return to value investing following COVID-19 and its pivot to international ESG equities management.

Perpetual on Thursday booked a 43 per cent slide in interim profit to $29 million for the six months ended December.

The profit fall came despite a 13 per cent lift in revenue to $284 million, which the company attributed to newly-created divisions in the business that have split asset management into Australian and international units.

Underlying profit fell a more benign 11 per cent to $53 million, when excluding the costs of buying and integrating new international fund managers Trillium and Barrow Hanley.

Perpetual will pay an interim dividend of 84¢ per share, equal to about 90 per cent of profits.

Mr Adams, whose $2 billion ASX-listed Perpetual specialises in active equity management, said the new Australia and international divisions had delivered improved investment performance “materially benefiting from the current shift towards value stocks that began in late 2020″.

Over the six months ended December, Perpetual continued to struggle to attract flows into its local funds despite its Australian equities, cash and fixed income strategies outperforming the group’s benchmarks.

Assets under management fell to $22.7 billion, hit by a $1.7 billion redemption by a large institution that pulled a cash mandate. That was down from $26.3 billion this time a year ago, or a fall of 14 per cent.

“Whilst our net flows for the period were disappointing, Perpetual’s investment teams have performed strongly for our clients during the half,” Mr Adams said.

For decades, Perpetual has deployed a value investing style aimed at buying out-of-favour stocks priced below their fundamental value by the market, in the hope of profiting when the market catches up.

However, the style has lagged sharemarkets during an era in which tech stocks and blue chips have sharply outperformed other stocks, leading to fund outflows at loyal value fund managers.

Assets under management in the Australian division fell in every channel (retail, intermediary, institutional) aside from inflows from listed investment vehicles.

Mr Adams was, however, upbeat on the prospects for ESG inflows, particularly into Trillium, where its global equity fund and its global sustainable opportunities fund outperformed their benchmarks by 3.8 per cent and 8.4 per cent, respectively, since inception.

Perpetual over the period completed acquisitions of US-based fund managers Trillium Asset Management and Barrow, Hanley, Mewhinney & Strauss, and Mr Adams said both Perpetual and Barrow Hanley equities teams had improved performance, which “augurs well” for increased inflows into the group’s funds “into the future”.

Assets under management for Perpetual’s international strategies has ballooned thanks to the acquisitions, rising from $5.6 billion last to to $66.5 billion at the end of December.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: Star scraps dividend as profit and revenue slump
relatedPosts.body:
Star Entertainment Group has scrapped its interim dividend after half-year net profit after tax dived 33.1 per cent to $51 million from a revenue take that slumped to 29.6 per cent to $741.4 million.

The gaming giant’s results come a week after the scathing report into Star’s rival Crown Resorts, which found its casinos facilitated money laundering and had been infiltrated by organised crime via its lucrative VIP international junket program.

Star management told investors it will engage with the regulator in relation to the recommendations of the Bergin Inquiry, the 18-month probe by the former NSW Supreme Court Judge Patricia Bergin SC which recommended banning junkets .

The gaming giant put its results down to “extraordinary challenges and significant impacts of COVID-19″.

“The Group continued executing its growth strategy despite the extraordinary challenges and significant impacts of COVID-19,” said chairman John O’Neill.

He insisted the fundamental earnings prospects for The Star’s domestic business remain unchanged because they are “underpinned by valuable long-term licences in compelling locations.”

He also cited the continued work on Queen’s Wharf Brisbane and The Star Gold Coast and the “upgraded and expanded Sovereign at The Star Sydney delivered on time and budget”.

The group runs Star in Sydney’s Pyrmont, the second-largest casino in Australia after Melbourne’s Crown Casino.

No dividend was declared – a 10.5¢ interim dividend was paid last year – because the “Star remains committed to maintaining a balance sheet that positions the Group for the post-COVID-19 recovery”.

“The board has not declared an interim dividend for 1H FY2021 as a cash dividend cannot be paid until gearing (net debt/trailing 12-month statutory EBITDA) is below 2.5 times, which was a condition for the June 2020 covenant waiver,” the company told the ASX.

relatedPosts.headline: Coonan’s pay up $1.8m as Crown sinks to $120m loss
relatedPosts.body:
Crown Resorts executive chairman Helen Coonan will get a pay rise of $1.8 million, bringing her annual pay to $2.5 million as she attempts to steer the embattled casino giant clear of the taint of being found unfit to run a casino in Sydney.

Crown Resorts sank to a $120 million loss in the December-half. Revenue collapsed 62 per cent to $581 million and management put the loss down to the severe impact on the company’s operations from the COVID-19 pandemic, in particular its Crown Melbourne casino which had to close for most of the half due to government imposed restrictions.

The $6.9 billion casino giant also scrapped its dividend.

Former NSW Supreme Court judge Patricia Bergin’s scathing report, released last Tuesday, found the board turned a blind eye to money laundering, physical risks to staff and junket tour providers with links to criminal Triad gangs.

Ms Helen Coonan became executive chairman on an interim basis on Monday after Crown Resorts chief executive Ken Barton stepped down following the scathing report.

Ms Bergin SC’s report found the gambling giant had facilitated money laundering through its bank accounts, disregarded the welfare of its China-based staff before several were arrested in 2016, and partnered with junket operators linked to organised crime.

Andrew Demetriou, a former AFL chief executive and a Crown director since 2015, was singled out by Commissioner Bergin who found it would “justified” if the regulator lacked confidence in him after his performance at the inquiry.

Commissioner Bergin also said the company had to curb the influence of billionaire shareholder James Packer over it if it were to ever become fit enough for the casino, which prompted Mr Packer’s private company, Consolidated Press Holdings (CPH), to withdraw his board representation.

His nominees to the board, Michael Johnston – who also came under heavy criticism in the Bergin report – and Guy Jalland, resigned.

CPH ceased engagement with its third board nominee, Mr Poynton, who is now considered an independent director, and there is speculation CPH will sell down its 37 per cent stake.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: CSL profit jumps 45pc as flu business soars
relatedPosts.body:
Blood products giant CSL notched up its fastest profit and revenue growth in recent years despite a uniquely challenging first half, after its flu business delivered an “exceptionally strong” performance.

Net profit surged a massive 45 per cent to $US1.8 billion ($2.32 billion) in the six months to December 31, while revenue leapt 16.9 per cent to $US5.7 billion. Usually, low double-digit revenue growth is considered a strong result.

“I am pleased to report a strong result in an unprecedented time of uncertainty during the most severe pandemic of our lifetime,” chief executive Paul Perreault said.

“Our core franchise, the immunoglobulin portfolio, has continued to perform well led by our market leading subcutaneous product Hizentra.

Sales of CSL’s Hizentra product grew strongly, up 19 per cent, reflecting the benefits of home administration and the continued strong uptake for the treatment of the debilitating neurological disorder CIDP (chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy).

The company declared a dividend of $US1.04 per share, up 9 per cent.

Despite the strong first half result - which exceeded consensus expectations by about 25 per cent - the company maintained its full-year guidance of net profit of $US2.17 billion to $US2.265 billion at constant currencies, representing growth of 8 per cent.

The steady guidance meant that shares in the $131 billion biotech company had increased just 2.47 per cent to $288.12 by lunchtime Thursday. This is substantially down on the 12-week high of $342.75, achieved this time last year before COVID-19 triggered mass lockdowns worldwide.

Overall, CSL Behring sales leapt 11 per cent, while Seqirus’ revenue climbed 38 per cent.

“The pandemic has tempered the performance of CSL Behring while boosting the performance of Seqirus,” Mr Perreault said.

One of the biggest risks to CSL in the near term is people in the US not donating plasma, as they stay home due to the pandemic.

On Thursday, the company revealed lower plasma collections were likely to have an impact on the company in the future years.

The company has also closed the door on new patients wanting its immunoglobulin therapies, preferencing its existing customers.

While the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine has been approved, CSL was also involved in producing the University of Queensland’s COVID-19 vaccine candidate, which was unsuccessful.

Analysts had not factored in any upside to CSL from its vaccine efforts.

As well as making COVID-19 vaccines, CSL spearheaded a global alliance to develop a hyperimmune convalescent plasma-based product using the antibodies of recovered COVID-19 patients to treat seriously ill patients.

Internationally this hyperimmune is phase three trials, while a similar clinical trial in Australia is going through a phase one trial.

“If successful this will become one of the earliest treatment options for hospitalised COVID-19 patients,” Mr Perreault said.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: Wesfarmers lifts interim dividend after bumper result
relatedPosts.body:
Wesfarmers managing director Rob Scott said he felt more confident now than he did six months ago and believed the group’s retail businesses would continue to thrive even as the COVID-19 vaccine was rolled out and consumers became more confident getting out and about.

Wesfarmers’ Bunnings, Officeworks, Kmart and Target chains thrived during the pandemic as consumers forced to spend more time at home stocked up on hardware and gardening supplies, home office equipment and educational needs and homewares.

The group’s retail sales grew 19.2 per cent in the December-half, 1.5 times the overall growth in Australian retail sales excluding food.

However, there are fears that as the vaccine is rolled out, snap lockdowns are no longer necessary, borders reopen, interstate travel becomes less risky, people return to the office and resume their pre-COVID lifestyles, demand for discretionary goods will fall.

Coles managing director Steve Cain warned on Wednesday that supermarket retailers and other winners from the pandemic faced a reckoning in coming months as they cycled sales and profits inflated by unprecedented growth in spending.

Mr Scott said he was a lot more optimistic than he was six months ago but there were still some risks and some uncertainties on the horizon.

Wesfarmers lifted its interim dividend by 17 per cent after December-half net profit jumped 23.3 per cent to $1.39 billion, swelled by bumper profits at Bunnings, Officeworks and Kmart.

However, the $61 billion conglomerate did not issue a special dividend or announce a share buy-back, even though Wesfarmers is rolling in cash after selling assets including two-thirds of its stake in Coles for more than $2 billion. Some investors were hoping for a $1 a share capital return.

The net profit result for the six months ending December 31 was struck on sales of $17.8 billion, up 16.6 per cent, and included $34 million ($24 million after tax) of restructuring costs at Kmart Group, which is closing or converting 167 Target stores.

Before one-off costs, net profits rose 25.5 per cent to $1.41 billion, beating consensus forecasts around $1.29 billion, despite $30 million in COVID-19 related costs and the group’s decision to pay pandemic leave to staff when stores were closed during the three-month lockdown in Melbourne.

Earnings before interest and tax rose 25.2 per cent to $2.17 billion as strong double-digit profit growth at Bunnings, Kmart Group and Officeworks offset weaker profits in the energy, chemical and fertilisers business.

Bunnings, which accounts for almost 60 per cent of group profits, was once again the star performer. Earnings rose a better than 35.8 per cent to $1.27 billion as total sales jumped 24.4 per cent to $9 billion and same-store sales rose 27.7 per cent (vs 4.7 per cent in the year-ago period) even though the hardware retailer was forced to close its stores in Melbourne for three months.

Officeworks and Kmart Group also did better than expected despite store closures and COVID costs.

Officeworks’ earnings rose 22 per cent to $100 million as sales rose 23.7 per cent to $1.5 billion, with higher sales of low margin technology products and higher labour costs crimping margins.

Profits from the Kmart Group rose 42 per cent to a record $487 million (before one-off costs) as sales rose 9 per cent to $5.4 billion. Both Kmart and Target faced widespread stock shortages but cut back on promotions, boosting margins, and converted Target stores performed well.

Online retailer Catch, which was acquired in June 2019 for $230 million, benefited from the acceleration in online spending, with gross transaction values rising 95.6 per cent. However, Catch’s earnings were impacted by increased investment in technology, marketing and fulfilment capacity to support future growth.

Excluding the Catch marketplace, online sales across the group grew 125 per cent to $1.4 billion. Including Catch online sales in the half reached $2 billion, equivalent to online sales for the entire 2020 year.

WesCEF’s earnings fell 7.5 per cent to $160 million as revenues decreased 6.6 per cent to $830 million. Earnings were hurt by increased competition in ammonium nitrate, weaker gas prices and weaker export demand in the sodium cyanide business as a result of international gold mine closures due to COVID-19.

In the industrial and safety division, which includes Blackwoods, Workwear and Coregas, earnings before one-off costs rose 68 per cent to $37 million as sales rose 4.7 per cent to $898 million. Earnings in the year-ago period were hit by payroll remediation costs.

Wesfarmers expected to incur COVID costs of about $10 million per quarter, down from $15 million a quarter in the first-half.

Mr Scott said the decision to pay an 88¢ a share fully franked dividend (up from 75¢ a share last year) reflected Wesfarmers’ strong result and balance sheet but also available franking credits, credit metrics and the need to preserve flexibility to manage continued uncertainty associated with the pandemic and to take advantage of value-accretive growth opportunities.

Wesfarmers paid an 18¢ special dividend and a final dividend of 77¢ last year.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: ANZ profits jump, unwinds provisions
relatedPosts.body:
ANZ has joined its rivals in reporting a sharp rise in quarterly cash profit and has written back $150 million worth of provisions as the economic outlook improves, and Australian banks power out of the virus crisis.

The bank reported an unaudited cash profit from continuing operations of $1.81 billion, up 54 per cent from the average of the last two quarters of 2020 and 156 per cent from the average of the first two quarters.

The bank has also followed in the steps of rival Westpac and released or written back a net $150 million in provisions or around 10 per cent of the total, after winding back collective provisions by $173 million and adding an individual assessed provision of $23 million.

ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott said the write back reflected a more optimistic outlook for the bank however he cautioned that snap lockdowns underscored the fragility of the recovery.

“The small release in the collective provision reflected improved economic conditions, particularly here in Australia,” Mr Elliott said.

“However, recent lockdowns in Perth, Brisbane, Melbourne and Auckland demonstrate how quickly things can change, and we believe our current settings are both prudent and appropriate given this uncertainty,” Mr Elliott said.

ANZ shares rallied at the open and by 11am were 64.5¢ or 2.5 per cent higher to $26.46, the highest in almost 12 months. Westpac shares gained by a similar margin, NAB shares were flat and CBA continued its trajectory lower as investors took profits.

ANZ took $1.7 billion in collective provisions in 2020 in anticipation of higher unemployment and weaker house prices however targeted government support measures had softened the blow and delivered the bank additional flexibility.

ANZ also updated the market on the state of its deferred loan book which was down significantly from the peak with just 1 per cent of home loan customers in Australia and New Zealand receiving COVID-19 support. The bank assisted around 145,000 customers over the course of 2020.

The bank only has 15,000 home loans worth $6 billion still frozen down from 96,000 loans valued at $33 billion. Business loans continue to be slightly more stubborn with the bank holding 2,500 SME loans worth $1 billion down from 23,800 loans worth $10 billion at the peak.

The bank said that new deferrals or extensions have not been offered to customers since January 31 in preparation for the end of concessional capital treatment for frozen loans from the regulator as of March 31.

ANZ said revenues increased by 4 per cent for the quarter excluding the volatile markets business. Mr Elliott said it achieved market share gains in the Australian home loan market and record home loan volumes in New Zealand.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: Chanticleer’s view: Elliott’s big worry isn’t what you think
relatedPosts.body:
In November, ANZ chief executive Shayne Elliott told his board his biggest worry was COVID-19.

But it wasn’t the virus itself or the volatility it created that worried him.

As Elliott told Chanticleer on Thursday, the bank’s results for the December quarter demonstrated it “wasn’t rattled by last year”.

The 54 per cent surge in cash earnings to $1.8 billion was underpinned by revenue growth, cost reduction and the release of 10 per cent of the $1.7 billion worth of COVID-19 credit provisions taken last year, showing ANZ has been able to balance strong operational performance with prudent support for customers.

Instead, Elliott’s big COVID-19 concern was that worrying about the virus would overwhelm ANZ’s strategy. “It’s that we become obsessed with COVID … and we miss the big game and what is really going on.”

What’s going on, Elliott says, is a period of incredible change as banking is essentially unbundled. The idea that a bank could be everything to everyone – transaction accounts, personal loans, mortgage, credit card – is disappearing because of changing consumer behaviour and the rise of fintech.

Elliott argues banks will increasingly have to choose what they will and won’t do, and use partnerships and alliances to both differentiate their product offering from their rivals and free up capital to invest in key growth areas.

ANZ’s focus areas are emerging: mortgages, small business and the institutional banking market. But the refining of its growth strategy is a work in progress.

Take mortgages.

Trying to become a big mortgage factory churning out the lowest rate in the market wouldn’t be sensible for ANZ, which has a market share of 15 per cent.

But Elliott says a product suite that sees customers through the property life cycle – saving for a home, finding a home, buying that home, living in that home, renovating that home and upgrading to a new home – would be more differentiated, more tailored and, no doubt, offer better margins.

But ANZ won’t manufacture all the products in that suite. Instead, it’s likely to do more of what it did late last year when it formed a joint venture with a $34 billion French giant called Worldline to provide merchant services to SME customers.

This was a business that ANZ was OK at, but not great. By partnering with Worldline it gave customers a better service and freed up capital to invest in other areas.

Elliott says it’s a template ANZ can use further in the coming years as it narrows its focus. Big data and API technology, which lets banks seamlessly integrate products from partners into their own systems, is opening up a raft of possibilities, he says.

The challenge for ANZ – and really any big bank – is getting the balance right between growth, rewarding shareholders who saw dividends dive last year, and maintaining the foundations that have seen the banks sail through the pandemic.

relatedPosts.headline: Forrest scoops $1.6b as Fortescue beats dividend estimates
relatedPosts.body:
Fortescue Metals Group has confirmed a $US400 million blow out on its Iron Bridge project as it announced a record dividend worth $1.64 billion to chairman Andrew Forrest.

Fortescue also said in future it would pump 10 per cent of net profits toward the subsidiary (Fortescue Future Industries) that is scouring the world for renewable energy project opportunities.

Fortescue will pay a $1.47 per share interim dividend on the back of a $US4.08 billion half year profit.

Analyst consensus measured by VUMA pointed to a $US4.09 billion underlying profit for the six month period, and an interim dividend of $1.329.

The big payout continues an extraordinary period of wealth generation for Fortescue’s chairman and major shareholder, who owns just over 36 per cent of the company.

Mr Forrest’s entities received $1.96 billion of dividends from Fortescue in fiscal 2020 and $1.24 billion of dividends the previous year.

Fortescue’s bumper dividend comes after rival iron ore miners BHP and Rio Tinto paid dividends earlier this week that were much bigger than expected.

The best financial results in Fortescue’s history have been overshadowed this week by the exit of three executives, including high profile operations boss Greg Lilleyman, over the Iron Bridge blow outs.

Fortescue said on Thursday the project was now expected to cost $US3 billion rather than $US2.6 billion, but a further 12 weeks of detailed studies would be conducted to investigate a range of logistical issues around the project.

Transportation of the magnetite concentrate from the mine to Port Hedland will be a particular focus; the existing plan was for pipelines to carry the concentrate to the port as a slurry.

But Fortescue indicated it would study whether the project could make more use of the rail and port infrastructure that carries Fortescue’s existing iron ore products to Port Hedland.

The investigation into different transport options comes after Fortescue last year asked WA regulators to tweak its approvals because of the potential for the Iron Bridge magnetite to be handled differently at Port Hedland.

Iron Bridge’s concentrate was once expected to have its own shiploaders and berths at Port Hedland to allow the concentrate to be sold as a discrete product, but Fortescue told WA regulators last year the concentrate may be blended into the company’s existing iron ore stockpiles at Port Hedland.

The cost blow outs were mostly blamed on a higher than expected Australian dollar and inflationary pressures in Western Australia where the hard state border has made life difficult for a buoyant resources industry.

Since approving the project in April 2019, Fortescue and its project partners have spent $US1.1 billion; much less than was expected to be spent by now under the original spending schedule.

Fortescue effectively owns just over 60 per cent of the project, with Taiwanese conglomerate Formosa owning 31 per cent while Chinese steel giant Baowu indirectly owns just over 8 per cent of the project.

Iron Bridge will be delivered several months later than expected in late 2022.

relatedPosts.headline: Chanticleer’s view: Wesfarmers back on the road to electric car future
relatedPosts.body:
They say that with age comes wisdom. The latest major investment by 106-year-old grand old conglomerate Wesfarmers is a case in point.

Since Wesfarmers chief executive Rob Scott first announced in May 2019 that it was buying lithium mining hopeful Kidman Resources and its Mount Holland project, sentiment around lithium has oscillated wildly.

Just 12 months ago, with lithium prices in the toilet and the balance sheets of producers looking badly stretched, Scott announced that he and joint venture partner, the global lithium giant Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile (SQM), would take an extra year to work on planning for the project before making a final investment decision.

Lo and behold, the lithium price is getting off the canvas and lithium stocks on the ASX are surging. And on Wednesday night, just ahead of the release of Wesfarmers’ stellar December-half profit numbers, Scott announced he was pushing the button on Mount Holland and an associated production facility at Kwinana in Western Australia. Wesfarmers’ share of the capital required is $950 million, funded out of existing cash and debt.

While lithium sentiment has clearly turned in the last six months – helped in part by surging momentum around the globe to drive the transition to clean energy – Scott insists very little has changed in Wesfarmers’ confidence around the opportunity created by rising demand for electric vehicle batteries.

“There’s a lot of speculative interest in lithium … but as we said at the outset this is a long-term project,” he says.

Shifts in the external environment have mattered far less than the changes made by Wesfarmers and SQM to the project itself to give greater certainty on engineering design and increase capacity at Kwinana by 11 per cent to 50,000 tonnes a year. The joint venture will also invest to ensure it could quickly double capacity at a later date.

There’s still a long way to go here – construction starts in the second half of this calendar year with first production three years after that – but Wesfarmers has provided a neat lesson in long-term thinking.

Thursday brought a result that highlighted the financial firepower that makes these sorts of investments possible.

Group profit surged 25.5 per cent to $1.4 billion with growth from Wesfarmers’ retail businesses – Bunnings, Officeworks, Kmart and Target – running at 19 per cent, or 1.5 times the wider retail market excluding food.

Bunnings was again the star, growing revenue 24 per cent and earnings 34 per cent in an impressive display of operating leverage.

Yes, the boost Wesfarmers has received from government stimulus and COVID-19 restrictions will fade, but its retail businesses will be stronger at the end of the pandemic than at the start.

relatedPosts.headline: China wine hit spoils cans jump for Orora
relatedPosts.body:
The chief executive of beverage cans and wine bottle maker Orora said he took a “gulp” when the size of the official provisional tariffs imposed by the Chinese government on 800 Australian wine producers was announced in November.

Brian Lowe said on Thursday that about 10 per cent of the group’s 900 million bottles produced at a large factory near Gawler in South Australia end up in China.

The short-term hole from the hefty tariffs of up to 212 per cent for wine bottle customers selling to China will drag earnings in the June half lower in Orora’s Australasian business.

This is despite heavy demand for beverage cans across its network of five factories making cans for beer, soft drinks and kombucha, stemming from pantry hoarding and robust in-home consumption.

Treasury Wine Estates, owner of brands including Penfolds and Wolf Blass, is the biggest customer of Orora in the wine sector, with Treasury Wines’ profits from China slumping 37 per cent for the December half as the tariff hit began to bite.

Mr Lowe said the immediate impact will pull earnings back for the Australasian division in the six months ended June 30.

“We expect to come back a little,” he said. Mr Lowe said he was quite stunned when the size of the tariffs on Australian wine producers of up to 212 per cent were announced.”

Treasury Wines was hit with tariffs of 169 per cent. Australian wine producers had been exporting $1.3 billion of wine annually to China.

In contrast, the company’s beverage cans business is experiencing strong demand, driven by the swing to in-home consumption and stronger sales through grocery outlets.

“It’s fair to say we are running pretty much flat out,” Mr Lowe said.

Earnings before interest and tax for the Australasian business was up 4.2 per cent to $86.1 million in the six months ended December 31.

In North America, where the company runs packaging operations and a business which supplies in-store visual merchandise to retailers, EBIT was up 12.7 per cent to US$39 million.

Orora kept its dividend steady at 6.5¢, with bottomline net profit after tax marginally ahead at $97.4 million.

Mr Lowe said Orora was carefully assessing potential expansion into the beverage containers sector in North America.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: South32 may seek NSW government intervention over coal snub
relatedPosts.body:
South32 may seek NSW government intervention over the rejection of a life extension for its Illawarra coking coal business and says the surprise decision is a reminder of how difficult coal approvals are in Australia.

Rejection of the mine extension has raised concerns about the viability of the nearby BlueScope steelworks at Port Kembla, and South32 chief executive Graham Kerr said the NSW process had denied his company the chance to counter claims against the project.

South32’s Dendrobium mine is due to exhaust reserves by 2024 and the company was surprised earlier this month when a request to extend the mine life to 2048 was rejected by NSW’s Independent Planning Commission (IPC) over concerns about the impact on Sydney’s drinking water catchments.

Mr Kerr said South32 was yet to decide whether to appeal the decision, seek a government intervention, to submit a revised application or to simply accept the judgement.

NSW deputy premier John Barilaro has declared his desire to overturn the IPC’s Dendrobium decision and has indicated he could use courts or legislation to do so, but Mr Kerr stopped short of endorsing any particular intervention path.

The Port Kembla steelworks sits at the end of an integrated infrastructure network that carries coking coal from South32’s mines, and BlueScope has warned it could face major capital and recurring costs if it were forced to rely on imported coal.

He said South32 would consider the merits of alternative mine plans for Dendrobium before deciding whether to appeal or seek a government intervention.

Major approval decisions in NSW were outsourced to an independent, quasi-judicial body in 2010 at the suggestion of the state’s Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) in a bid to reduce the risks of corruption.

“I am not saying there is anything wrong with an independent process understanding the background in NSW around what had happened previously,” said Mr Kerr.

“What we would be engaging with the government around (is) how that could actually be improved.”

The comments came as South32 reported an underlying half-year profit of $US136 million and a US1.4¢ dividend.

South32 said demand for its products has improved noticeably since the turn of the new year with its cash balance surging from $US254 million to $US452 million in January alone.

South32’s most important commodities are alumina, aluminium, manganese and coking coal, and prices for those commodities are now 8 per cent, 15 per cent, 14 per cent and 26 per cent higher than the average prices received in the six months to December 31.

The improved outlook prompted South32 to boost its existing “capital management program”, a reference to shareholder returns, by $US250 million.

The company said that boost meant there was $US259 million that would be returned to shareholders by September 3.

It is expected this money will be returned via a share buyback program.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: OZ Minerals warms to nickel as copper price runs hot
relatedPosts.body:
OZ Minerals boss Andrew Cole sees more blue sky ahead for red metal copper even with the price sitting at a nine-year high.

Mr Cole said copper producer OZ Minerals was warming to nickel amid a greater recognition of the key role both metals will play in the transition to renewable energy generation and storage.

The Oz Minerals’ $1 billion copper-nickel West Musgrave project in Western Australia is now attracting a lot of interest and is firmly on the company’s development radar.

OZ Minerals reported full-year net profit after tax of $213 million, up 30 per cent from $163.9 million last year.

It was the best result in a decade for OZ Minerals, which declared a fully franked final dividend of 17c a share, as it ramped up copper production at its Carrapateena mine in South Australia.

The result came as the company took advantage of the high gold price by eating into ore stockpiled at its Prominent Hill copper-gold mine.

OZ Minerals’ full-year revenue climbed by more than 21 per cent to $1.34 billion and underlying EBITDA by 31 per cent to $606 million.

“It is starting to get quite a bit of interest with our shareholders and the market more generally,” Mr Cole said.

“There are very, very few new copper or nickel projects in the build pipeline around the world so when something like this comes up it does attract attention.”

OZ Minerals is in the final stages of assessing the project but has applied for environmental approval from the WA regulator and is deep in discussions with local indigenous communities about their expectations around any development.

Mr Cole said OZ Minerals faced a crunch decision next year about whether it was best placed to own and develop West Musgrave.

“We are not ready to make a decision on whether we should build, own and operate or bring on a partner or sell the asset,” he said.

“That is not a decision for today but I think by next year it will be a decision.”

Mr Cole said OZ Minerals was now much more comfortable with nickel as a commodity.

With copper prices sitting at a nine-year high of about $US3.89 a pound, or more than $US8570 a tonne, Mr Cole predicted the commodity would go from strength to strength with supply under pressure and demand increasing.

Goldman Sachs and Citi have raised their 12-month target price to $US10,000 a tonne.

Full story here.

relatedPosts.headline: Chanticleer’s view: What we learnt: Woodside, Seven Group
relatedPosts.body:
Outdoing Woodside boss Peter Coleman is pleased to get a torrid 2020 behind him. The $US4 billion ($5.2 billion) loss he announced on Thursday, mainly due to massive write-downs caused by lower oil and gas prices, neatly explains why.

But Coleman also believes 2020 brought acceleration in many of the factors that give Woodside optimism about the outlook for LNG.

Put simply, five years of downwardpressure on oil supply increased last year, as the drop in the oil prices saw even more energy companies pump the brakes on new projects. The momentum in the global energy transition has also seen oil majors shift their attention to renewables.

With new supply constrained, the recovery in demand following the pandemic should be supportive for oil and gas prices. Woodside is already seeing this in its area of focus, the North Asian LNG market. But Coleman believes this is only the start of a period of normalisation in energy markets he has long predicted.

It’s also a good backdrop for the long-delayed final investment decision for Woodside’s Scarborough project. Coleman has always said the company needed a few quarters of better prices before it could hit the button; the company can now prepare for the big decision in the second half of this calendar year safe in the knowledge its view on the supply/demand balance is coming to fruition.

Big trucks helps Seven to big Boral gain

Seven Group chief executive Ryan Stokes is feeling pretty good about the progress new Boral chief executive Zlatko Todorcevski is making at the building materials company.

And why not? Since Seven started buying Boral stock on March 16 last year, the stock is up 76 per cent, with Seven’s 20 per cent stake valued at $1.26 billion. Todorcevski has a long way to go in his turnaround, but this is already looking like a handsome winner for Seven.

But that Stokes was willing and able to make that investment last year, when many in the market were raising capital or paying down debt, speaks to the confidence provided by Seven’s operating businesses and particularly the WesTrac mining equipment division, which again performed well in the December half.

Earnings before interest and tax rose 14 per cent to $211.4 million in the half, as new equipment was commissioned for big projects at BHP (South Flank) and Rio Tinto (Koodaideri). With a string of new projects yet to ramp up – including Fortescue’s Eliwana and Iron Bridge projects and Newmont Boddington project – and the big iron ore miners demonstrating plenty of confidence about the outlook, Stokes is understandably confident in the near-term outlook for WesTrac.

EBIT at Coates rose 1 per cent as Seven delivered good cost cuts to offset a 7 per cent decline in revenue. Stokes remains confident that the rush of infrastructure projects long predicted will arrive, but COVID-19 is introducing a degree of uncertainty that will require Coates to remain lean and flexible.
